intro: Primula farinosa var. armena, commonly known as Armenian primrose, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of the Caucasus and parts of Turkey. It is characterized by its low-growing habit, with hairy stems and rosettes of broad, waxy leaves. The plant produces clusters of bell-shaped, violet or purple flowers during the spring season. It thrives in cool, moist environments and is often found in alpine meadows and rocky soils. Due to its ornamental value and unique appearance, it is cultivated in gardens and botanical collections.
